Article Journal of
Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Vol. 16, 7325–7336, 2016
www.aspbs.com/jnn
Magneto-Optical Properties of Reusable Spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4(0.0≤ x ≤ 1.0) Nano-Catalysts
E. Hema1, A. Manikandan2 ∗, P. Karthika1, M. Durka3, S. Arul Antony2, and B. R. Venkatraman4 ∗
1Department of Chemistry, Kunthavai Naacchiyaar Government Arts College for Women (Autonomous) Thanjavur 613007, Tamil Nadu, India
2PG and Research Department of Chemistry, Presidency College (Autonomous) Chennai 600005, Tamil Nadu, India 3Department of Physics, A.V.V.M Sri Pushpam College (Autonomous), Poondi, Thanjavur 613503, Tamil Nadu, India
4PG and Research Department of Chemistry, Periyar E.V.R. College (Autonomous), Tiruchirappalli 620023, India
Magnetically recyclable spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0) nanocatalysts were successfully synthesized by a simple urea-assisted microwave combustion method. The formation of single-phase cubic spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 nano-structures were confirmed by powder XRD, Rietveld refinement XRD method, FT-IR and EDX analysis. The morphology of the samples consists of spherical shaped particle-like nano-crystal structure with well crystalline nature, which was confirmed by HR-SEM, HR-TEM and SAED analysis. The optical properties, band gap (Eg and defect states of the samples were confirmed by UV-Vis DRS and PL spectroscopy and the Eg of undoped spinel MgFe2O4 sample is 1.81 eV and it is increased with increasing the amount of Ni2+ dopant, due to the decrease of particle size. The magnetic measure ents (VSM) showed ferromagnetic behavior for all compositions and the magnetization values are increased with increasing the Ni2+ dopant, due to the higher magnetic moment (2 B) of Ni2+ ions substituted the non-magnetic nature of Mg2+ ions (0 B) in the spinel MgFe2O4 lattice. The surface area of the samples increased with increasing the concentration of Ni2+ ions upto x = 0.0–0.6 and further increasing the Ni2+ ions (x = 0.8 and 1.0), it is decreased. The higher surface area of the sample Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs showed better catalytic conversion (96.08%) of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde with 100% selectivity.
Keywords: Spinel Ferrites, Nanoparticles, MgFe2O4, Optical Properties, Magnetic Properties, Nano-Catalyst.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
In recent years, nanostructured spinel magnetic materials with desired morphologies have been the subject of much interest, because of their unusual optical, electronic, magnetic and catalytic properties, which often differ from their same bulk materials.1–3 Spinel ferrites have the general formula of A2+(Fe3+ 2O4 (where A2+: Mg, Co, Ni, Zn, etc.) and unit cell contains 32 oxygen atoms in cubic close packing with 8 tetrahedral (A−) and 16 octahedral (B−) occupied sites. By changing type of the divalent cation, it is possible to obtain significantly different physico-chemical and magnetic properties in these ferrites.4–6 Nowadays, Spinel ferrites have
∗Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed.
become an important in nano-science and nanotechnology field, due to their huge applications in various fields such as biomedicine, magnetic materials, electronic materials, optical materials, biomedicine and catalysts.7–11 There is a growing interest on mixed nano-ferrite systems in the last decades, due to their remarkable physical, chemical and structural properties owing to their extremely small size, large specific surface area and a number of promising applications. Several ions such as magnetic (Mn2+, Ni2+, etc.) and non-magnetic (Zn2+, Cd2+, etc.) cations have been used as substituent in spinel ferrites by many researchers, in order to improve their optical, electrical, magnetic and catalytic properties.9–11 Among various mixed nano-ferrites, Mg–Ni ferrite nanostructures have been widely used in different fields such as magnetic, catalytic materials and gas sensors.12–14
J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 2016, Vol. 16, No. 7 1533-4880/2016/16/7325/012 doi:10.1166/jnn.2016.11109 7325
Delivered by Ingenta to: State University of New York at Binghamton IP: 5.101.221.84 On: Thu, 06 Oct 2016 18:48:01
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
Spinel ferrites have been synthesized by various methods such as solid-state reaction, co-precipitation, hightemperature self propagating, ball milling, microemulsion, solvothermal, mechano synthesis, hydrothermal, sol–gel, hydrothermal and combustion techniques.15–33 However, the above said methods reveal that requirement of complicated equipment, high-energy consuming, high temperature, long time consuming and complex procedures are required for synthesis of such functional spinel ferrite nano-materials. Moreover, complex processes, expensive precursors and low production rates are common problems to many of these techniques. Hence, the growth of simple and environmentally benign synthesis methods is strictly essential for the preparation of such active spinel ferrite nanostructures with higher production rates and purity preferred with low energy cost.9 11
Nowadays, microwave irradiation is becoming an increasingly popular method of synthesis of simple and mixed metal oxides. In the present study, we have reported a facile microwave-assisted combustion method for the synthesis of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 (0.0≤ x ≤ 1.0) nanocatalysts. It offers a clean, cheap and convenient method of heating, which often results in higher yields with purity and shorter reaction times. Organic compounds (e.g., glycine, urea, citric acid, alanine and carbohydrazide) have been mixed directly with metal nitrates to enhance the efficiency of combustion synthesis. The metal nitrates act both as oxidants and as well as cation sources, while the organic compounds act as the fuels.34 The microwave heating mechanism is fundamentally different from the conventional heating process. Microwave radiation is absorbed and converted into thermal energy, and the heat is generated from inside the material and distributed homogeneously through the materials interior, in contrast to conventional heating methods, where heat is transferred from the outside. This internal rapid heating allows a dramatic reduction of processing time and consumed energy. Also, this method offers many advantages, such as simplicity, high crystallinity of the products and its adequacy for the preparation of large quantities of materials without the need of higher sintering temperature.35–37
Nowadays, magnetic materials especially, spinel ferrites nanomaterials has been used extensively as a heterogeneous catalyst and it can be recovered easily from the reaction mixture by applied magnetic field and reused several times and making the process more economically and environmentally viable. Spinel ferrite heterogeneous catalytic nano-materials play a very important role in the selective oxidation of functional groups in ways that are economically advantageous and environmentally friendly.25 38–44 Moreover, the catalytic activity of the spinel ferrite nano-catalysts significantly depends on the distribution of cations among the available A- and B-sites in the spinel lattice. Ramankutty and Sugunan25 investigated various spinel MFe2O4 (Cu, Ni and Co) prepared
by the room temperature co-precipitation route with high surface area and the sample CoFe2O4 nano-catalyst display the best performance than others. Yan et al.42 reported citrate assisted sol–gel method of various spinel MFe2O4 (Cu, Ni, Co, Zn) by using EDTA as a templating agent by hydrothermal method. They found that the spinel CoFe2O4 nano-catalyst display the best performance, whereby 93% selectivity of benzaldehyde was achieved at close to 63% conversion, whereas, CuFe2O4 catalyst using H2O2 oxidant with 57.30% conversion and 89.50% selectivity. Hankare et al.43 reported the oxidation of benzyl alcohol over spinel ferrite catalyst using H2O2 oxidant with 79.80% conversion and 98.30% selectivity. However, the detailed study on the effect of Ni2+-doping on structural, morphological, optical, magnetic and catalytic properties of spinel MgFe2O4 nano-crystals synthesized by urea-assisted microwave combustion method has not yet been reported. The goal of this study is to synthesize spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 (where x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) nano-catalysts by an alternative and relatively new microwave assisted combustion method, using urea as a fuel, and investigate its structural, morphological, optical, magnetic and catalytic properties. We have investigated the relationship between catalytic activity, crystallinity, particle size, surface area and morphology of NixMg1−xFe2O4 (0.0≤ x ≤ 1.0) spinel nano-crystals in detail.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and Methods
sections.text:
All the chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade obtained from Merck, India and were used as received without further purification. Magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO3 2 ·6H2O, 98%), nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3 2 ·4H2O, 98%), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3 3 · 9H2O, 98%) and urea (CO(NH2 2 as the fuel are used for this microwave combustion method. The samples were prepared with the addition of Ni2+ of different molar ratios (NixMg1−xFe2O4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 1 0) nano-catalysts) to MgFe2O4. In case of NiFe2O4, the precursor mixture in urea was placed in a domestic microwave oven and exposed to the microwave energy in a 2.45 GHz multimode cavity at 850 Watts for 10 minutes. Initially, the precursor mixture boiled and underwent evaporation followed by the decomposition with the evolution of gases. When the solution reached the point of spontaneous combustion, it vaporized and instantly became a solid. The obtained solid powders were washed well with ethanol and dried at 80 C for 1 h, and labeled as MgFe2O4, Ni0 2Mg0 8Fe2O4, Ni0 4Mg0 6Fe2O4, Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4, Ni0 8Mg0 2Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4, respectively, and then used for further characterizations. The proposed microwave-assisted combustion reaction may be as follows:
Ni NO3 2 ·6H2O S +2Fe NO3 3 ·9H2O S +6 66CO NH2 2 S

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterizations
sections.text: The structural characterization of Ni-doped MgFe2O4 (NixMg1−xFe2O4 with x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) NPs was performed using a Philips PAN analytical X’ pert PRO diffractometer equipped with a Cu tube for generating a Cu K radiation (wavelength 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV, 25 mA. Structural refinements using the Rietveld method were carried out by PDXL program; both refined lattice parameters and crystallite size of the obtained ferrites were reported. The surface functional groups were analyzed by Thermo Nickolet FT-IR spectrometer. The samples were incorporated in KBr pellets for the measurements. Morphological studies and energy dispersive X-ray analysis of undoped and Ni-doped MgFe2O4 nanocrystals have been performed with a Jeol JSM6360 high resolution scanning electron microscopy. The transmission electron micrographs were carried out by Philips-TEM (CM20). The surface area was derived from the N2 adsorption– desorption isotherms using liquid nitrogen at 77 K using an automatic adsorption instrument (Quantachrome Corp. Nova-1000 gas sorption analyzer). The UV-Visible diffuse reflectance spectrum was recorded using Varian Cary 5E UV/VIS-NIR UV-Visible spectrophotometer to estimate their band gap energy (Eg . The photoluminescence properties were recorded at room temperature using Perkin Elmer LS 55 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer. Magnetic measurements were carried out at room temperature using a PMC MicroMag 3900 model vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) equipped with 1 Tesla magnet.

sections.heading: 2.3. Catalytic Test
sections.text: The oxidation of benzyl alcohol using spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) catalysts were carried out in a batch reactor operated under atmospheric conditions. 10 mmol of oxidant (H2O2 was added along with 1 g of nano-sized catalysts (MgFe2O4, Ni0 2Mg0 8Fe2O4, Ni0 4Mg0 6Fe2O4, Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4, Ni0 8Mg0 2Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4 and the contents were heated at 80 C in an acetonitrile medium for 10 h in a three necked round bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser and thermometer. The oxidized products after the catalytic reaction are collected and studied using Agilent GC spectrometer. The column used for the study was DB wax column (capillary column) of length 30 mm and helium was used as the carrier gas.

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphological Studies
sections.text:
The morphologies of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 samples were investigated by the high resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) and the obtained results are shown
in Figure 1. Figures 1(a)–(d) shows the HR-SEM images of undoped MgFe2O4, Ni0 4Mg0 6Fe2O4, Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4 samples, respectively. HR-SEM images indicated that the as-prepared samples consist of spherical shaped particle-like nano-crystals, which are agglomerated together, due to the presence of magnetic interactions among the particles.45
To provide a further evidence for the formation of sphere-like nano-particle morphology of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 samples, high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) analysis was carried out and is shown in Figure 2. Figures 2(a), (b) shows the HRTEM images of Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 samples with diameter ranging from 16–20 nm. It is obvious that the spherelike nanoparticles are uniform in size, which is consistent with the average crystallite size obtained from the peak broadening in XRD and Rietveld analysis. The nano-sized features are noticeably visible in Figure 2(b), which was found to be highly crystalline as evident form HR-TEM images. Figure 2(b) shows the inter-planar distance d spacing of 0.283 nm can be assigned to the (311) lattice plane of the cubic spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs. Figure 2(b), inset shows the selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) of spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs, which implies that the as-prepared samples are single crystalline in nature. SAED results show spotty ring characteristic of small crystallites of spinel ferrite nanostructure without any additional diffraction spots and rings of secondary phases corresponding to the magnesium, nickel and iron oxides were observed. From the SAED pattern there are seven noticeable diffraction rings, the positions of which match well with standard spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 samples.

sections.heading: 3.2. Elemental Composition Analysis
sections.text: The purity and elemental composition of the spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) NPs were recorded by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis. Figures 3(a)–(c) shows the EDX results of spinel MgFe2O4, Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4 NPs, respectively. Figure 3(a) shows the peaks of Fe, Mg and O elements in undoped MgFe2O4 and Figure 3(b), shows the peaks of Fe, Mg, Ni and O elements for Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 samples. However, Figure 3(c) shows the peaks of Fe, Ni and O elements in spinel NiFe2O4 samples and there are no other peaks, which are confirmed the as-synthesized samples are pure and there is no other impurity. A small peak was appeared at 2.1 KeV for all compositions, which indicated the presence of Au peak, which has been used as a sputter coating for preparing the sample for HR-SEM analysis to show the better visibility of the surface morphology.

sections.heading: 3.3. Structural Analysis
sections.text:
The structural phase, crystalline nature and purity of the prepared spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs were confirmed by analyzing the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern. Figure 4(a), (b) shows the XRD patterns of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs prepared with various Ni substitutions (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0). The main diffraction peaks (2 appear at about 29.96 , 35.27 , 37.25 , 43.14 , 53.56 , 56.85 , 63.23 and 74.12 , which are attributed to the (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), (440) and (533) planes, respectively, show the characteristics of a single-phase cubic spinel structure with JCPDS Card No. 73-1720 for MgFe2O4 and JCPDS Card No. 74-2081 for NiFe2O4 (Fd3m space group)
46 47 samples, and all diffraction peaks can be indexed typical NixMg1−xFe2O4 spinel structure. There is no evidence of the presence of -Fe2O3 phase was observed, because typically this phase is predictable at relatively low temperatures. Figure 4(b) indicates that the centers of the two most intense peaks (220), and (311) are slightly shifted towards the lower diffracted angles with increasing the concentration of Ni2+ dopant, which is attributed to the difference in the ionic radii of Ni2+ (0.78 Å) and Mg2+ (0.65 Å) ions; also the results confirmed the presence

The calculated crystallite sizes of the samples are summarized in Table I. It has been observed that the crystallite size is decreased from 20.65–17.04 nm with increase in Ni2+ content, upto x = 0.0–0.6. Further increasing the concentration of Ni2+, ions (x = 0.8 and 1.0) the crystallite size increased from 18.72 nm to 19.48 nm. The results show a

significant amount of XRD line broadening, a characteristic of nano-phase materials.48
In order to further analyze the structural change, the measured XRD patterns of the NPs were simulated based on the Rietveld refinement method for all compositions. Figures 5(a), (b) shows the Rietveld XRD data of MgFe2O4 and Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs respectively. Rietveld XRD was designed to refine simultaneously both lattice constant and crystallite size. The obtained values of lattice parameter and crystallite size from Rietveld analysis are shown in Figure 6 and Table I. The lattice parameter of undoped MgFe2O4 is 8.386 Å
49 and it is increased with increasing Ni2+ content from 8.392 Å to 8.418 Å, thus obeying Vegard’s law. However, the increase of lattice parameter is mainly due to the higher ionic radius of Ni2+ ions (0.78 Å)50 than smaller ionic radius of Mg2+ ion (0.65 Å),46 and thus causes an effective increase in the lattice constant. A linear increase in the lattice constant thus indicates that the Ni2+ ions are replacing the Mg ions in spinel MgFe2O4 matrix. 51 52

sections.heading: 3.4. Functional Groups Analysis
sections.text:
Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was used to analyze the functional groups of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) NPs and are shown in Figure 7. The entire samples exhibit band around at 3420 cm−1 and 1620 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations of O–H groups of water molecule. From the FT-IR spectra, it was found
J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 16, 7325–7336, 2016 7329
Delivered by Ingenta to: State University of New York at Binghamton IP: 5.101.221.84 On: Thu, 06 Oct 2016 18:48:01
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
that two strong absorption peaks observed at lower frequency (830 and 435 cm−1 can be assigned to the M– O (Mg, Ni and Fe) bonds at A- and B-sites.53 This can be attributed to the high degree of crystalline nature of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs. The obtained results were good agreement with Rietveld refinement XRD and SAED analysis. The aforementioned two peaks also confirmed the formation of A- and B-sites structures. Similar results are reported earlier by salah et al.48

sections.heading: 3.5. Optical Properties
sections.text:
To study the effect of crystallite size and band gap of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) NPs, the UV-Visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) analysis was carried out at room temperature for all compositions. The Eg of the samples can be evaluated using Kubelka-Munk method. It allows the calculation of the absorption coefficient ( by the measurement of UVVisible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-Vis DRS), and it
is mainly used for powder samples. Kubelka-Munk function, F R is directly proportional to the absorption coefficient ( and the value is estimated. Thus the vertical axis is converted into quantity F R which is equal to the absorption co-efficient. Thus the ‘ ’ in the Tauc equation is substituted with F R and hence the relation becomes,
F R = = 1−R 2
2R (2)
where, F(R is Kubelka-Munk function, ‘ ’ the absorption coefficient, ‘R’ the reflectance. Thus the Tauc relation becomes, F R h = A h −Eg n (3) where n = 1/2 and 2 for direct and indirect transitions, respectively, thus giving direct and indirect band gaps. The plots of (F R h 2 versus h for all compositions are shown in Figure 8(a). Extrapolation of linear regions of these plots to (F R h 2 = 0 gives the direct band gap values. The calculated Eg for all compositions are summarized in Table I. The estimated band gap (Eg values of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0 to 1.0) nano-crystals

are 1.81, 1.96, 2.09, 2.15, 2.22, and 2.31 eV, respectively (Fig. 8(b) and Table I). It was found that there is increased in the Eg with increasing the concentration of Ni2+ ions in spinel MgFe2O4 NPs. The Eg value of undoped spinel MgFe2O4 NPs is 1.81 eV, and it increased from 1.96 eV (x = 0.2) to 2.31 eV (x = 1.0), which is mainly attributed to the reduction in crystallite size of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 nano-crystals as Ni2+ ions (x= 0.0 to 1.0) increased, due to the quantum confinement effect and size effect. Shen et al.54 reported similar band gap value of 1.81 eV for spinel MgFe2O4 NPs. The Eg value of bulk MgFe2O4 is 2.0 eV, and hence there is a red shift for x = 0.0 and 0.2 and blue shift for all other compositions (x= 0.4 to 1.0). The observed shift in Eg value of the spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs with the decreasing crystallite size is the result of quantum confinement effects arising from the small size regime.55
Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy is an effective method to study the electronic and optical properties of the semiconductor metal oxides. PL spectra was recorded at room temperature to detect the optical properties of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs (x = 0.0 to 1.0) and are shown in Figure 9. All the samples were excited by using the excitation wavelength at 410 nm. The PL spectrum clearly shows the characteristic near-band-edge (NBE) emission at around 423 nm, which can be assigned to intrinsic defects, mainly interstitial metal defects, and is attributed to the recombination of electrons deeply trapped in oxygen vacancies with photo-generated holes.56 However, a strong peak appear at around 565 nm, which clearly show the band gap value of the as-prepared samples, and also consistent with the calculated band gap values by KubelkaMunk method. The increase of the concentration of Ni2+ dopant, the overall PL peak intensities for all compositions increased, which can be attributed to the appearance of new electronic levels between conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) and might be due to the increase
in intrinsic defects such as oxygen vacancies. However, there are four minor peaks detected by the PL spectrometer at around 433, 488, 504 and 565 nm for all compositions, which may be due to the oxygen defects. Thus, the employed microwave-assisted combustion method can produce plenty of defects in spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 x = 0.0 to 1.0) NPs.

sections.heading: 3.6. Magnetic Properties
sections.text:
The room temperature magnetization measurements for the spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs with different Ni2+ contents (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) were performed on a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) and the resultant magnetic hysteresis, M–H curves are shown in Figure 10. Figure 10 inset clearly indicated that the prepared spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 nano-catalyst can be separated from water by the application of external magnetic field. From the VSM measurements, saturation magnetization (Ms , remanent magnetization (Mr and coercivity (Hc values are evaluated and are reported in Table II (Fig. 11(a)–(c)). These curves are typical for a soft magnetic material and indicate hysteresis ferromagnetism in the field ranges of ±10 KOe for all compositions. Spinel MgFe2O4 is a soft magnetic material and the non-magnetic Mg2+ in MgFe2O4 is substituted by magnetic Ni
2+ ions (2 m), there is a drastic change in magnetic properties such asMs, Mr and Hc. Outside these ranges the value of Ms increased with increasing the concentration of Ni2+. The values Ms were obtained to be 32.79, 37.96, 43.98, 52.69, 57.95 and 63.76 emu/g for the samples MgFe2O4, Ni0 2Mg0 8Fe2O4, Ni0 4Mg0 6Fe2O4, Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4, Ni0 8Mg0 2Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4, respectively (Table II). The change in the value of Ms is most probably due to the difference in the cation distribution at the A- and B-sites. Khot et al.57 reported the cation distribution of spinel MgFe2O4 sample, the non-magnetic Mg
2+ ion concentration at the A-site is 12%, while that on the B-site is 88%,
J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 16, 7325–7336, 2016 7331
Delivered by Ingenta to: State University of New York at Binghamton IP: 5.101.221.84 On: Thu, 06 Oct 2016 18:48:01
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
which gives a mixed spinel system. The magnetic nature of Ni2+ (2 B) ions has preference to both A- and B-sites of the spinel lattice. The incorporation of high magnetic nature of Ni2+ (2 B) ions into the B-sublattices instead of non-magnetic Mg2+ (0 B) ions leads to a greater increase in the magnetic moment per formula unit of the B-site when compared with the A-site. However, site preference of cations depends on their electronic configurations. Also, the occupancy of Ni2+ ion in A-site allows the Fe3+ ions to migrate from A- to B-site and willingly increased the overall magnetic moment.58 However, the very low value of Hc and Mr indicates the soft magnetic nature of NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs.59 Kumar et al.60 reported magnetic nature of Ni2+ ion doped ZnFe2O4 (NixZn1−xFe2O4: x = 0.1, 0.3, 0.5) NPs and they found that the doping effect of Ni2+ ions, the Ms values are increased from 23.95 emu/g to 37.75 emu/g with increasing Ni2+ content (x = 0.1–0.5). From the results, it is clearly understood that the magnetic properties of the samples are affected by the composition, cation distribution, concentration and nature of dopant.61 The decrease in Mr and Hc with the increase in Ni content can also be attributed to the reduction in the number of spins occupying the A sub-lattices, causing the net magnetization to increase with increase in Ni concentration.62–64

sections.heading: 3.7. Catalytic Property
sections.text:
It has been usually accepted that the crystallinity, particle size, concentrations of doping metal ions and morphologies of the materials are significant factors that influence its catalytic performance. The present study, leads to enhance the catalytic activity of spinel MgFe2O4 with the adition of Ni2+ catalyst (NixMg1−xFe2O4: x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0). The influence of Ni2+doping on MgFe2O4 NPs on the efficiency is evaluated as shown in Figure 12. However, the catalytic efficiency of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) is increased with an increase in the concentration of Ni loading and showed a maximum activity at x = 0.6 (Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 . In order to have an idea of the adsorbance capability of the NPs, BET surface area analysis was determined using N2 adsorption/desorption studies. BET surface areas of MgFe2O4, Ni0 2Mg0 8Fe2O4, Ni0 4Mg0 6Fe2O4, Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4, Ni0 8Mg0 2Fe2O4 and

NiFe2O4 NPs are 59.91, 63.78, 68.57, 71.42, 69.43, and 68.17 m2/g, respectively (Table III). The surface area is increased with increasing the concentration of Ni content (x = 0.6) and the sample Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs was found to be higher surface area (71.42 m2/g) and provide

Delivered by Ingenta to: State University of New York at Binghamton IP: 5.101.221.84 On: Thu, 06 Oct 2016 18:48:01
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
more contact area for the reactants and catalyst, which is mainly due to their high surface-to-volume ratio with higher surface area than other samples. In general, a high specific surface area has a favorable effect on the activity for the heterogeneous catalysts. Therefore, it is believed that the high surface area of Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs could enhance the catalytic activity than other samples (Fig. 12 and Fig. 13). The catalytic efficiency of undoped MgFe2O4 nano-catalyst is very low when compared with Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs. It is mainly due to the smaller particle size distribution of Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs and more surface defects as demonstrated in PL spectra.
Therefore, the improvement in the catalytic efficiency of NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs as Ni doping increases was recognized to the small particle size and higher defect application. However, the sample Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs showed maximum activity for the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol, which may be due to the smaller grain size. In addition, when the size of particles decreases, the amount of the dispersion of particles per volume in the solution will increase, which resulting the enhancement of the absorbance. However, undoped MgFe2O4 and undoped NiFe2O4 relatively poor performance was detected, which were possible due to their bigger particle size with lower
Table III. BET surface area and conversion efficiency of spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) nano-catalysts.
BET surface Samples area (m2/g) Conversion (%) Selectivity (%)
MgFe2O4 59.91 87.28 100 Ni0 2Mg0 8Fe2O4 63.78 89.19 100 Ni0 4Mg0 6Fe2O4 68.57 92.42 100 Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 71.42 96.08 100 Ni0 8Mg0 2Fe2O4 69.44 95.67 100 NiFe2O4 68.18 93.15 100
surface area. Usually, the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to produces a mixture of benzaldehyde, benzoic acid and benzyl benzoate. However, benzoic acid and benzyl benzoate were not obtained in this present study. Therefore, the catalyst was found to be highly selective. Usually, catalyst with a high specific surface area would offer more surface active sites and catalytic reaction centers, resulting in the enhancement of catalytic performance. Thus the higher surface area of spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs may lead to higher catalytic activity, as compared to other samples. In addition, when the size of particles decreased, the amount of the dispersion of particles per volume in the solution will increase, which resulting the enhancement of the catalytic performance. The amount of catalyst is very important in catalysis. The catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol was found to be increased with increase in the amount of Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs up to 0.5 g, and further increase in catalyst amount showed negative effect as illustrated in Figure 14 (Table IV). This may be due to that the increase in the amount of catalyst increased the number of active sites on the surface, which in turn increase the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde. When the amount of Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 nano-catalyst increases above the optimum value, the oxidation is decreased, due to the appearance of turbidity and deposition on the catalyst surface and hence the efficiency of the oxidation reduced. Furthermore, the increase in catalyst concentration beyond the optimum may result in the agglomeration of catalyst particles; hence, the part of the catalyst surface and active catalytic sites becomes unavailable and thereby, catalytic efficiency decreased. The proposed catalytic mechanism of the spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 nano-catalyzed reaction of acetonitrilehydrogen peroxide medium is shown in Figure 15. Initially, solvent acetonitrile can activate the oxidant H2O2

Catalyst amount (g)
Figure 14. Effect of the amount of catalyst on the catalytic efficiency (Reaction conditions: Catalysts (Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 , 0.1–0.8 g; benzyl alcohol, 5 mmol; Acetonitrile, 5 mmol; H2O2, 5 mmol; temperature, 80 C, time, 5 h).
and forming a perhydroxyl anion (OOH− , which is nucleophilically attacks the nitrile to generate an intermediate peroxycarboximidic acid. It is well known that the formed intermediate is a good oxygen transfer agent. The benzyl alcohol and the oxidant H2O2 dissolves in acetonitrile, which activate H2O2 into OOH
− anion and forming Mg– OOH− species.65 This account revealed that the phenyl ring and the OH group of benzyl alcohol interact with Mg2+ ion of MgFe2O4 and the inner active sites remains intact. The interaction of phenyl ring and OH group with the outer metal ions of MgFe2O4 is also evident by the adsorption of phenyl ring on MgFe2O4. However, the catalyst surface gets regenerated by the action of the oxidant, which leads to desorption of the product molecules, thereby favoring further oxidation. Hence, this process is of great interest for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde. It is noted that not only the conversion of benzyl alcohol, but also the benzaldehyde selectivity was higher. In addition, H2O2 has been proved to be very efficient and environmentally friendly oxidant, since the product is only aldehyde.65
The recyclability of nano-catalyst is very important for industrial and technological applications. The catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde was
Table IV. Amount of spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 catalyst (0.1 to 0.5 g) for the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde.

employed as a model reaction to investigate the reusability of spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 nano-catalyst. The reusability of nano-catalyst for the liquid phase oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde was evaluated and the results are shown in Figure 16. The percentage yield versus number of cycles for the reusability of spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 nano-catalyst is shown in Figure 16. For this purpose, the sample was filtered off from each run and washed several times with ethanol and dried at 110 C in an air oven for 2 h and was checked for five consecutive runs under the same conditions. During the five runs investigated, the conversion of benzyl alcohol was in a range from 96.08 to 95.13% indicating that the catalyst displays good reproducibility and stability. Interestingly the formation of benzoic acid was not detected. Since the spinel Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 nano-catalyst is able to oxidize benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde with high activity, highly recyclable, remarkably stable and environmental friendly, they are promising candidates for the industrial applications.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
We successfully applied a facile, low-cost microwave assisted one-pot flash combustion method to synthesize nanocrystalline spinel NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs from nitrate precursors and urea as the fuel. It was found that the structural, morphological and opto-magnetic properties are sensitively dependent on the incorporation of Ni2+ ions in the spinel MgFe2O4 lattice. On doping of Ni
2+ ions in MgFe2O4 lattice, the ferromagnetic behavior increased from x = 0.0 to 1.0, which changes the shape of M–H loops. The magnetization at the maximum field monotonically increased with increasing Ni2+ ions, which is attributed to the change in the cationic distribution at A- and B-sites. Smaller values of the coercivity showed the soft magnetic nature of the NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs. The present study lead to enhance the catalytic activity of NixMg1−xFe2O4 NPs with the addition of Ni2+ ions, and the sample Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs showed higher catalytic activity than the other samples, due to the very smaller particle size distribution with higher surface area would be a potentially efficient catalyst and high crystallinity, which significantly influence on the enhanced catalytic activity. The higher surface area of the sample Ni0 6Mg0 4Fe2O4 NPs showed better catalytic conversion (96.08%) of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde with 100% selectivity. The presented microwave assisted synthesis method is rather straightforward and easy to handle for the preparation of bulk ferrite powders that can be applied to simple or complex oxide systems.
